data.question: What is the detection limit for mercury(II) ions using UV−vis spectroscopy in homogeneous aqueous solutions for N719?
Which dye changes color from dark red-purple to orange in the presence of mercury(II) salts when supported on nanoporous TiO2 films?
What is the estimated limit of quantification for mercury(II) detection using N749 in ethanol?
Can the N719-sensitized TiO2 film be reused for sensing after being exposed to mercury(II)?
What causes the color change in N719 and N749 dyes in the presence of mercury(II) ions?
data.answer: The direct coordination of mercury(II) ions to the sulfur atom of the NCS groups

data.question: Is the interaction of mercury(II) ions with the NCS groups of the ruthenium dyes selective when compared with other metal ions?
What is the role of iodide ions in the reversibility of the mercury−dye interaction?
data.answer: Iodide ions form a stable mercury−iodide complex that displaces the mercury from the ruthenium complex.

data.question: Does the N749 dye show a bigger color change than N719 upon interaction with mercury(II) ions?
What is the estimated detection limit for mercury(II) ions using N749 supported on mesoporous TiO2 films?
Is the mercury−dye interaction reversible for both N719 and N749?
What method is used to estimate the detection limit for mercury(II) ions in homogeneous aqueous solutions?
What happens to the color of N749 dye in the presence of mercury(II) salts?
data.answer: It changes from dark green to pink

data.question: Is the interaction of mercury(II) ions with N719 and N749 selective against lead(II), cadmium(II), zinc(II), or iron(II)?
What is the effect of adding iodide ions to the mercury−dye complex?
data.answer: The mercury ion can be removed and the solid-supported molecular probe reused for sensing.

data.question: What is the color change observed for N719 dye in the presence of mercury(II) salts?
Does the N749 dye undergo a dramatic color change only in the presence of mercury(II) salts?
What is the role of thiocyanate groups in the colorimetric mercury sensing by N719 and N749?
data.answer: Mercury(II) ions coordinate reversibly to the sulfur atom of the dyes' NCS groups, inducing a color change.

data.question: Can the color change of N719 and N749 dyes be observed with the naked eye?
What is the detection limit for mercury(II) ions using UV−vis spectroscopy in homogeneous aqueous solutions for N749?
Is the interaction of mercury(II) ions with the NCS groups of the ruthenium dyes irreversible?
